title: Angie Best snaps at professor delaying menopause with surgery
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Angie Best shocked Good Morning Britain viewers with her views on delaying menopause, describing the natural transition as an ‘amazing time’.

The former model came face-to-face with Professor Simon Fisher who has pioneered a surgical procedure that ‘tricks a woman’s biological clock into thinking they’re younger than they are’.

They keyhole surgery involves removing a small piece of ovarian tissue that is then sliced up and frozen in an ice bank to preserve it.

When a woman enters menopause, that tissue is thawed out and some are grafted back into the body under her arm for example, or somewhere near the ovaries if she is experiencing fertility issues.

This will awaken the woman’s body and kickstart biological hormones from when she was fertile, flushing the woman’s estrogen and stopping the menopause in its tracks.

Professor Fisher believes it’s a better option than hormone replacement therapy (HRT), but Angie argues it’s just men trying to tell women what to do with their bodies.

Fisher said on Good Morning Britain: ‘Why not use our body to overcome some of the very severe problems that women have in regards to menopause.

Angie and Professor Fisher disagreed over the method of delaying menopause (Picture: ITV)

‘But the younger you do it, we’re also preserving a woman’s fertility. [Although] this is not about trying to create geriatric pregnancies.’

Angie, 67, admitted she loved the idea of delaying menopause but said women should try to opt for natural ways.

‘It sounds fabulous, I love anything to help with the ageing process but for me, something natural. If women take responsibility for their own individual bodies, the idea of there being such an invasive surgery to take out a piece of my ovary – only a man would come up with this,’ she argued.

However, Fisher said he has taken the lead from two female professors on developing the surgery, stating: ‘Women are part of our medical science here.’

Angie replied: ‘It sounds like a fantastic thing for someone who has problems with fertility, a problem with cancer, but for an ordinary woman going through menopause, it is just not necessary to have an invasive surgery.

‘Menopause is the same as puberty but on the other end of the scale.

‘Learn how to manage your hormones, learn why your hormones get out of kilter and you can do it yourself.’

However, Angie earned a strong reaction from viewers when she went on to describe the menopause process as an ‘amazing time’.

‘Babes, the menopause is an amazing time for a woman. You get rid of those daft hormones that make you crazy, jealous and emotional. You have no more periods, you are free. All of a sudden you feel wise and wonderful – well I do anyway,’ she said.

Angie thinks natural methods should be used to delay menopause (Picture: ITV)

Fisher argued that the surgery is ‘not that invasive’, stating: ‘It’s keyhole surgery. It’s done everyday on women, all over the world. We know from our cancer patients that 95% of women…’

But Angie interrupted him and snapped: ‘Simon, stop. Stop using cancer and menopause in the same [sentence].’

Reacting to the debate, one GMB viewer quipped: ‘Delaying #brexit now delaying the menopause and it’s not even the 1st of April.’

Disagreeing with Angie’s views on menopause, another chimed in: ‘Wouldn’t say the menopause is an amazing time Ang.’

Another wondered: ‘What plant is she on. There’s nothing ‘wonderful’ about the menopause!’

‘F**k that. I’d rather go through the menopause at 50 than at 70!!!!!!’ another stated.
